text.value: Partly by using words like “bidding” and “yoke”, the voice of Patience presents God as dynamic and busy. In the last five lines of the poem, the servants of God (which some critics suggest are angels, not men) are described using six third person singular verb forms (one is used twice) relating to their work (whether active or passive). Highlight these seven verbs.

“God doth not need
Either man’s work or His own gifts. Who best
Bear His mild yoke, they serve Him best. His state
Is kingly: thousands at His bidding speed,
And post o’er land and ocean without rest;
They also serve who only stand and wait.”

The servants of God fulfil the mystical property of omnipresence, yet paradoxically God cannot go places if he is everywhere - so in a sense it is most godlike to be still, especially standing in the presence of God.
